revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = 1971 killing of Bengali intellectuals | partof = the [[1971 Bangladesh genocide]] | image = 1971 intellectuals.JPG | image_size = 300px | alt = | caption =A sculpture in Meherpur showing the execution of intellectuals by the Pakistan Army in 1971 | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = [[East Pakistan]] | target = [[Bengali people|Bengali]] intellectuals | coordinates = | date = 25 March 14 – 16 December 1971 | type = [[Deportation]], [[ethnic cleansing]], [[mass murder]] | fatalities = 1,111{{cite book |last=Khan |first=Muazzam Hussain |year=2012 |chapter=Killing of Intellectuals |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Killing_of_Intellectuals |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}} | injuries = | victims = | perps = [[Pakistani Armed Forces]]
[[Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami|Jamaat-e-Islami]]
[[East Pakistan Central Peace Committee|Shanti committee]]
[[Razakars (Pakistan)|Razakars]]
[[Al-Badr (East Pakistan)|Al-Badr]]
[[Al-Shams (East Pakistan)|Al-Shams]] | susperps = | weapons = | numparts = | dfens = | motive = }} {{Campaignbox Bangladesh Liberation War}} In 1971 the [[Pakistan Army]] and their local collaborators, most notably the extreme right wing [[Islamist]] militia groups [[Al-Badr (East Pakistan)|Al-Badr]], engaged in the systematic execution of [[Bengali people|Bengali]] pro-liberation intellectuals during the [[Bangladesh liberation war]] of 1971, a [[war crime]]. Intellectuals were killed during the entire duration of the war. The largest number of executions took place on 25 March and 14 December 1971, as it became apparent that Bangladesh would become independent. 14 December is commemorated in Bangladesh as [[Martyred Intellectuals Day]]. == Black Night of 25 March == {{Expand section|date=December 2015}} At the beginning of [[Operation Searchlight]], on the night of 25 March 1971, a number of professors from [[Dhaka University]] were killed.Annual Report: Dhaka University 1971–72, Dr. Mafijullah Kabir{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/48049.pdf |title=Telegram 978 From the Consulate General in Dacca to the Department of State, March 29, 1971, 1130Z |website=US Department of State |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090808144647/http://www.state.gov/documents/organization/48049.pdf |archive-date=8 August 2009}} == Reason behind the killing == Since the establishment of the State of [[Pakistan]], the rulers of West Pakistan discriminated against citizens of East Pakistan and denied them civil and political rights.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} The discrimination was visible in all disciplines and the attack on the language and culture was direct. As a result, the discontent and anger in the minds of Bengalis turned to political and cultural protests and these movements were led by intellectuals from all parts of the society. They encouraged and seeded the idea of nationalism in the heart of Bengalis through social and cultural activities. As a result of their cultural movement, the people of East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) gradually became aware of their rights which turned the movement towards political protests.মুনতাসীর মামুন। । প্রকাশক: সময় প্রকাশন। আইএসবিএন 984-458-202-4। == 14 December executions == [[File:Dead bodies of Bengali intellectuals, 14 December 1971.jpg|thumbnail|Dead bodies of Bengali intellectuals found on 15 December 1971]] As the war neared its end, a final effort to wipe off as many intellectuals as possible took place, mostly planned between 12 and 14 December to eliminate the future leaders of the new nation.{{cite news|last=Hensher|first=Philip|title=The war Bangladesh can never forget|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/the-war-bangladesh-can-never-forget-8501636.html|newspaper=The Independent|date=19 February 2013}} On 14 December 1971, over 200 of East Pakistan's intellectuals including professors, journalists, doctors, artists, engineers, and writers were picked up from their homes in Dhaka by the Al-Badr militias and Pakistani Army. Notable novelist [[Shahidullah Kaiser]] and playwright [[Munier Choudhury]] were among the victims. They were taken blindfolded to torture cells in Mirpur, Mohammadpur, [[Nakhalpara]], Rajarbagh and other locations in different sections of the city. Later they were executed en masse, most notably at Rayerbazar and Mirpur. In memory of the martyred intellectuals, 14 December is mourned in Bangladesh as Shaheed Buddhijibi Dibosh [[Day of the Martyred Intellectuals]].{{cite news | url=http://www.newstoday.com.bd/index.php?option=details&news_id=2331520&date=2012-12-14 | title=DU set to observe Martyred Intellectuals Day, Victory Day | publisher=[[The News Today (India)|The News Today]] | accessdate=14 December 2012}} It is widely speculated that the killings of 14 December was orchestrated by Maj Gen [[Rao Farman Ali]]. After the liberation of Bangladesh a list of Bengali intellectuals (most of whom were executed on 14 Dec) was discovered in a page of his diary left behind at the Governor's House. The existence of such a list was confirmed by Ali himself although he denied the motive of genocide. The same was also confirmed by Altaf Gauhar, a former Pakistani bureaucrat. He mentioned an incident in which Altaf requested Ali to delete a friend's name from the list and Ali did that in front of him.{{cite book |last= Mamoon, Muntassir |author2= translation by Kushal Ibrahim |title= The Vanquished Generals and the Liberation War of Bangladesh |publisher= Somoy Prokashon |date=June 2000 | edition = First |isbn= 984-458-210-5| page = 29}} == Notable victims == Many notable intellectuals who were killed from 25 March to 16 December 1971 in different parts of the country include: * Gour Gopal Saha (academician) * Dr. [[Abul Fazal Ziaur Rahman]] (physician){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Rahman,_Abul_Fazal_Ziaur|title=Rahman, Abul Fazal Ziaur - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-15}} * Dr. [[ABM Nurul Alam]] (physician){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Alam,_ABM_Nurul|title=Alam, ABM Nurul - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-20}} * Dr. [[AFM Alim Chowdhury]] (ophthalmologist) * [[Ataur Rahman Khan Khadim]] (physicist){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Khadim,_Ataur_Rahman_Khan|title=Khadim, Ataur Rahman Khan - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-07-10}} * Dr. [[Atiqur Rahman (doctor)|Atiqur Rahman]]{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Rahman,_Atiqur|title=Rahman, Atiqur - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-13}} * Dr. [[Azharul Haque]]{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Haque,_Azharul|title=Haque, Azharul - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-25}} * Dr. [[AKM Asadul Haq]] * [[Altaf Mahmud]] (lyricist and musician) * [[ANM Golam Mostafa]] (journalist) * [[ANM Muniruzzaman]] (statistician){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Muniruzzaman,_ANM|title=Muniruzzaman, ANM - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-15}} * Dr. [[Anwar Pasha]] (Bengali literature) * Dr. [[Ayesha Bedora Choudhury]]{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Choudhury,_Ayesha_Bedora|title=Choudhury, Ayesha Bedora - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-07}} * [[Dhirendranath Datta]] (politician) * Dr. [[Faizul Mahi]] * Dr. [[Fazlur Rahman Khan (geologist)|Fazlur Rahman Khan]]{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Khan,_Fazlur_Rahman2|title=Khan, Fazlur Rahman2 - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-13}} * Dr. [[Govinda Chandra Dev]] (philosophy) * Dr. [[Ghyasuddin Ahmed]] * Dr. [[Jyotirmoy Guhathakurta]] (English literature) * Dr. [[Jekrul Haque]] (physician){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Haque,_Jekrul|title=Haque, Jekrul - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-15}} * Dr. Kalachand Roy (academic){{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/supplements/martyred-intellectuals-day-2017/my-great-mentor-dr-kalachand-roy-1504426|title=My great mentor, Dr Kalachand Roy|date=2017-12-14|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-12-13|language=en}} * Gour Gopal Saha (academician) * [[Khondakar Abu Taleb]] (journalist){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Taleb,_Khondakar_Abu|title=Taleb, Khondakar Abu – Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|access-date=20 November 2016}} * [[Khondakar Abul Kashem]] (history){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Kashem,_Khondakar_Abul|title=Kashem, Khondakar Abul – Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|access-date=20 November 2016}} * [[Meherun Nesa]] (poet) * [[Munier Chowdhury]] (Bengali literature) * Dr. [[Mufazzal Haider Chaudhury]] (Bengali literature) * [[Muhammad Habibar Rahman]] (mathematician){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Rahman,_Muhammad_Habibar|title=Rahman, Muhammad Habibar - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-07-15}} * Dr. [[Mohammad Sadat Ali]] (business){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Ali,_Mohammad_Sadat|title=Ali, Mohammad Sadat - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-05-12}} * [[Mohammad Shamshad Ali]] (physician){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Ali,_Mohammad_Shamshad|title=Ali, Mohammad Shamshad - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-15}} * [[Muhammad Shafi (dentist)|Muhammad Shafi]] (dentist){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Shafi,_Muhammad|title=Shafi, Muhammad - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-15}} * Dr. [[Abul Khair (Bengali intellectual)|M Abul Khair]] (history) * [[M Anwarul Azim]] iIndustrial administrator){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Azim,_M_Anwarul|title=Azim, M Anwarul - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-17}} * [[Mir Abdul Qayyum]] (psychologist){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Qayyum,_Mir_Abdul|title=Qayyum, Mir Abdul - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-15}} * Dr. [[Mohammed Fazle Rabbee]] (cardiologist) * Dr. [[Mohammad Mortaza]]{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Mortaza,_Mohammad|title=Mortaza, Mohammad - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-28}} * [[Mohammad Moazzem Hossain]] (educationist){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Hossain,_Mohammad_Moazzem|title=Hossain, Mohammad Moazzem - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-19}} * [[Mohammad Aminuddin]] (lawyer){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Aminuddin,_Muhammad|title=Aminuddin, Muhammad - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-25}} * Dr. [[Md Abdul Muktadir]] (geologist){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Muktadir,_Md_Abdul|title=Muktadir, Md Abdul - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-07-11}} * [[Nizamuddin Ahmed]] (journalist)[http://adnan.quaium.com/blog/56 Story of a Martyred Intellectual of 71’s war] * [[Nazmul Hoque Sarkar]] (lawyer){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Sarkar,_Nazmul_Hoque|title=Sarkar, Nazmul Hoque - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}} * Dr. [[Rashidul Hasan]] (English literature) * [[Ranadaprasad Saha]] (philanthropist){{cite news|url=http://www.daily-sun.com/details_yes_03-05-2013_ICT-issues-arrest-order-against-Mueen,-Ashrafuzzaman_485_1_2_1_0.html|title=ICT issues arrest order against Mueen, Ashrafuzzaman|date=3 May 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141208160743/http://www.daily-sun.com/details_yes_03-05-2013_ICT-issues-arrest-order-against-Mueen%2C-Ashrafuzzaman_485_1_2_1_0.html|archive-date=8 December 2014|location=Dhaka|newspaper=[[Daily Sun (Bangladesh)|Daily Sun]]|accessdate=3 November 2013|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/it-was-matricide/|title=It was matricide|last=Khan|first=Tamanna|date=4 November 2013|newspaper=The Daily Star|accessdate=7 November 2013}} * Dr. [[Rakhal Chandra Das]] (physician){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Das,_Rakhal_Chandra|title=Das, Rakhal Chandra - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-19}} * [[Sukharanjan Samaddar]] (Sanskrit) * [[Shahid Saber]] (journalist) * [[Sheikh Abdus Salam]] (educationist){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Salam,_Sheikh_Abdus|title=Salam, Sheikh Abdus - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}} * Dr. [[Sirajul Haque Khan]] * Dr. [[Santosh Chandra Bhattacharyya]]{{cite news |title=Gallows for Mueen, Ashraf |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/gallows-for-mueen-ashraf/ |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |date=3 November 2013}} * Dr. [[Shamsuddin Ahmed]]{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Ahmed,_Shamsuddin3|title=Ahmed, Shamsuddin3 – Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=8 March 2017}} * Dr. [[Suleman Khan (doctor)|Suleman Khan]]{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Khan,_Suleman|title=Khan, Suleman - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-02}} * [[Sultanuddin Ahmed]] (engineer){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Ahmed,_Sultanuddin2|title=Ahmed, Sultanuddin2 - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}} * Dr. [[Kosiruddin Talukder]]{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Talukder,_Kosiruddin|title=Talukder, Kosiruddin – Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=7 February 2017}} * [[Shahidullah Kaiser]] (journalist) * [[Selina Parvin]] (journalist) * [[Bishnu Chattopadhyay]] (freedom fighter and leader of peasant movement) * [[Saroj Kumar Nath Adhikari]] (economics) * [[Sheikh Abdul Mannan]] (journalist){{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Mannan,_Sheikh_Abdul|title=Mannan, Sheikh Abdul – Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|language=en|access-date=7 February 2017}} * Dr. [[Shamsuddin Ahmed]] (physician)http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Ahmed,_Shamsuddin3 {{Expand list|date=December 2015}} == Verdict on the killing == On 3 November 2013, a Special Court in Dhaka has sentenced two former leaders of the al-Badr killing squad to death for war crimes committed during Bangladesh's war of liberation in 1971. [[Chowdhury Mueen-Uddin]], a Muslim leader based in London, and [[Ashrafuz Zaman Khan]], based in the US, were sentenced in absentia after the court found that they were involved in the abduction and murders of 18 intellectuals – nine Dhaka University professors, six journalists and three physicians – in December 1971. Prosecutors said the killings were carried out between 10 and 15 December, when Pakistan was losing the war in Bangladesh (then East Pakistan), and were part of a campaign intended to strip the newborn nation of its intellectuals.{{cite news|title=UK Muslim leader Chowdhury Mueen Uddin sentenced to death in Bangladesh|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/uk-muslim-leader-chowdhury-mueen-uddin-sentenced-to-death-in-bangladesh-8919895.html|newspaper=The Independent|date=3 November 2013}} On 2 November 2014 [[International Crimes Tribunal (Bangladesh)|International Crimes Tribunal, Bangladesh]] sentenced [[Mir Quasem Ali]] to death for war crimes which include the killings of intellectuals. It was proved in the tribunal that he was a key organiser of the [[Al-Badr (East Pakistan)|Al-Badr]], which planned and executed the killing of the intellectuals on 14 December 1971.{{cite news|title=Bangladesh Islamist party leader files appeal against death penalty|url=http://www.shanghaidaily.com/article/article_xinhua.aspx?id=255697|accessdate=14 December 2014|work=[[Shanghai Daily]]}}{{cite news |title=War trial: Mir Quasem verdict Sunday |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/war-trial-mir-quasem-verdict-sunday-48077 |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |date=30 October 2014 |accessdate=14 December 2014}} == Statistics == The number of intellectuals killed is estimated in [[Banglapedia]] as follows: * Academics – 991 * Journalists – 13 * Physicians – 49 * Lawyers – 42 * Others (litterateurs, artists and engineers) – 16 The district wise break-up of the number of martyred academicians and lawyers published in 1972Bangladesh – The Victory Day Memento published by the government of [[People's Republic of Bangladesh]], 16 December 1972; Editor – Syed Ali Ahsan was as follows – :{| class="wikitable" ! rowspan=2| District and division ! colspan=3| Academics ! rowspan=2| Lawyers |- ! Primary ! Secondary ! Higher secondary |- | [[Dhaka]] | 37 | 8 | 10 | 6 |- | [[Faridpur, Bangladesh|Faridpur]] | 27 | 12 | 4 | 3 |- | [[Tangail]] | 20 | 7 | 2 | |- | [[Mymensingh]] | 46 | 28 | 1 | 2 |- ! '''Dhaka Division''' ! '''130''' ! '''55''' ! '''17''' ! '''10''' |- | [[Chittagong]] | 39 | 16 | 7 | 1 |- | [[Chittagong Hill Tracts]] | 9 | 4 | 1 | 1 |- | [[Sylhet]] | 19 | 7 | | 2 |- | [[Comilla]] | 45 | 33 | 1 | 4 |- | [[Noakhali]] | 26 | 13 | 4 | 2 |- ! '''Chittagong Division''' ! '''138''' ! '''73''' ! '''13''' ! '''10''' |- | [[Khulna]] | 48 | 15 | 2 | 2 |- | [[Jessore]] | 55 | 31 | 5 | 4 |- | [[Barisal]] | 50 | 21 | 4 | |- | [[Patuakhali]] | 3 | 1 | | |- | [[Kushtia]] | 28 | 13 | 4 | |- ! '''Khulna Division''' ! '''184''' ! '''81''' ! '''15''' ! '''6''' |- | [[Rajshahi]] | 39 | 8 | 3 | 5 |- | [[Rangpur, Bangladesh|Rangpur]] | 41 | 22 | 9 | 4 |- | [[Dinajpur District, Bangladesh|Dinajpur]] | 50 | 10 | 1 | 2 |- | [[Bogra]] | 14 | 12 | | 2 |- | [[Pabna]] | 43 | 9 | 1 | 2 |- ! '''Rajshahi Division''' ! '''187''' ! '''61''' ! '''14''' ! '''15''' |- ! '''Bangladesh''' ! '''639''' ! '''270''' ! '''59''' ! '''41''' |- | colspan=5| Martyred academicians (not affiliated to universities) = 968 |- | colspan=5| Martyred university teachers = 21 |- | colspan=5| Total martyred academicians = 989 |} Administrative districts and divisions mentioned here are as they were in 1972. == Commemoration == {{See also|Martyred Intellectuals Day|Martyred Intellectuals Memorial}} [[Martyred Intellectuals Day]] is held annually to commemorate the victims. In [[Dhaka]], hundreds of thousands of people walk to [[Mirpur Thana|Mirpur]] to lay flowers at the [[Martyred Intellectuals Memorial]]. The president and the prime minister of Bangladesh and heads of all three wings of the Bangladesh armed forces pay homage at the memorial.{{cite news |title=Nation observes new-dimension Martyred Intellectuals' Day |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/beta2/news/pm-pays-homage-to-martyred-intellectuals/ |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)]] |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=14 December 2012}} == See also == * [[1971 Dhaka University massacre]] == References == {{reflist|2}} {{Bangladesh liberation}} {{Military of Pakistan}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bengali Intellectuals}} [[Category:Bangladesh Liberation War]] [[Category:Political and cultural purges]] [[Category:Mass murder in 1971]] [[Category:Massacres in Bangladesh]] [[Category:1971 in Bangladesh]] [[Category:University of Dhaka]] [[Category:War crimes in Bangladesh]] [[Category:1971 Bangladesh genocide]] [[Category:Anti-intellectualism]] [[Category:Pakistani war crimes]] [[Category:Pakistan military scandals]]

revision.text:
'''BCeSIS''' (the '''British Columbia Enterprise Student Information System''') is the implementation of a common student information system by independent schools and school districts of [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]]. eSIS is commercial software developed by The Administrative Assistants Ltd of Ontario, Canada, that provides a foundation for a centrally hosted, web accessible [[student information system]].
==Background== The BCeSIS System is currently hosted by Fujitsu Canada under contract to the British Columbia Ministry of Education. Currently all districts have signed a [[memorandum of understanding]] to voluntarily adopt BCeSIS on their own timeline.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.sd42.ca/helpdesk_bcesis_description |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-01-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131025085616/http://www.sd42.ca/helpdesk_bcesis_description |archive-date=2013-10-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Support for schools and districts adopting the new system is provided by their own local staff resources in conjunction with Fujitsu Service Desk and the Ministry of Education. The Independent Schools of BC have pooled their resources as a consortium (the iGroup) and implementation/training and support of BCeSIS for Independent and First Nations School is handled by this consortium.
==Criticism==
===Social Criticism===
Some teachers dislike the system, believing it to be a tool of social control, centralizing potentially sensitive private information, and placing important decisions about student education in the hands of unelected committees with no background in education.<ref>http://bctf.ca/publications/NewsmagArticle.aspx?id=10454</ref>
===Poor User Interface===
The system also draws criticism for its archaic user interface. Some screens within the program allow arrow key movement, some functions use icons or multi-level text clicks, others require mouse clicks. The general design was not field tested on its intended users, nor was it tested on multiple browsers, and resulted in a poor user experience. For example, fields containing parent phone numbers only display the part of the number; a mouse click and arrow clicks are required to see the rest. Students lists (a typical class consists of 24–30 students) shows only thirteen names on the screen; one has to scroll down for the rest. Marks entry encounters similar design faults: sideways scrolling within student field-sets are required to access the three types of data typically entered (percent, work habits, comment selection). Combined with a start-up beset with server problems the introduction of BCeSIS was met with sharp anxiety and a call to examine whether the system was worth the $80 million expenditure.<ref>http://bctf.ca/publications/NewsmagArticle.aspx?id=17540</ref>
BCeSIS requires the use of outdated Java versions, as support for newer versions of Java was never implemented.<ref>http://bcsupportonline.com/common-bcesis-questions/java-error/</ref> There are many known serious security issues with the outdated version of Java required to run BCeSIS <ref>http://www.cvedetails.com/vulnerability-list/vendor_id-5/product_id-1083/version_id-104592/SUN-JDK-1.6.0.html</ref>
Using the Teacher Assistant interface, the teacher has access to the student demographics and contact information as well as details regarding the students' performance, programs and special education needs. BCeSIS gathers attendance in the classroom using an electronic attendance checklist and allows both the teacher and the office to share information regarding student absences. In an upcoming release of BCeSIS the province will be implementing a new capability called Parent Assistant that will allow parents to monitor their children's attendance and performance as it is entered into the system.
==Media Attention== BCeSIS drew media attention in September 2010 <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://communities.canada.com/vancouversun/blogs/reportcard/archive/2010/09/13/continued-frustration-with-school-software-known-as-bcesis.aspx |title=Archived copy |access-date=2010-09-25 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707113730/http://communities.canada.com/vancouversun/blogs/reportcard/archive/2010/09/13/continued-frustration-with-school-software-known-as-bcesis.aspx |archive-date=2012-07-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> for slow performance that hampered the efforts of schools to make timetable changes, process student transfers, and complete attendance. With new school district using the service, Fujitsu Service Desk was forced to limit the number of logins and post "BCeSIS unavailable" messages during peak usage hours. This compounded the performance issues and resulted in a number of internet parodies, including a re-subtitled scene from the movie [[Downfall (2004 film)|Downfall]].<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ql-iQE08qQo</ref>
On September 19, 2011, [[The Vancouver Sun]] reported that the Ministry of Education would be discontinuing use of the BCeSIS software, based on a recommendation by [[Gartner|Gartner, Inc]],<ref>https://vancouversun.com/pdf/bc_education_final_report.pdf</ref> and would likely not have a replacement in place until 2014.<ref>https://vancouversun.com/technology/schools+scrap+records+software/5422355/story.html</ref> The Minister of Education, [[George Abbott (politician)|George Abbott]], said that the system had glitches but was still good value for money, and was being replaced largely because the technology was outdated.
==Future==
BCeSIS is now being replaced by MyEducationBC. The first schools will be going live in September 2014. More information about implementation of MyEducationBC can be found at: https://web.archive.org/web/20140406113440/http://sisimplementation.ca/
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://archive.is/20130115162654/http://www.isw-bc.ca/ BCeSIS Main Website] * [http://bcsupportonline.com/ BCeSIS for Independent Schools] * [http://bcsupportonline.com/myeducationbc/ MyEducationBC MyEdBC for Independent Schools] * [https://csisc.ca/forum/ Common Student Information System Consortium] * http://fwix.com/vancouver/share/8283773e3f/give_us_back_our_bcesis_money_district_says *[http://www.aalsolutions.com/ creator of the software] {{Fujitsu}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = David Wechsler |image = |birth_date = January 12, 1896 |birth_place = [[Lespezi]], [[Kingdom of Romania|Romania]] |death_date = May 2, 1981 (aged 85) |death_place = [[New York City]], U.S. |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = |ethnicity = |field = [[Psychology]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale]],
[[Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children]] |influences = [[Charles Spearman]] |influenced = [[Alan S. Kaufman]] |prizes = |religion = }} '''David Wechsler''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|w|ɛ|k|s|l|ər}}; January 12, 1896 – May 2, 1981) was a Romanian-American psychologist. He developed well-known intelligence scales, such as the [[Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale]] (WAIS) and the [[Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children]] (WISC). A ''[[Review of General Psychology]]'' survey, published in 2002, ranked Wechsler as the 51st most cited psychologist of the 20th century.{{cite journal |last=Haggbloom |first=Steven J. |title=The 100 most eminent psychologists of the 20th century |journal=Review of General Psychology |volume=6 |issue=2 |year=2002 |pages=139–152 |doi=10.1037/1089-2680.6.2.139 |last2=Warnick |first2=Renee |last3=Warnick |first3=Jason E. |last4=Jones |first4=Vinessa K. |last5=Yarbrough |first5=Gary ., III| displayauthors=2}} ==Biography== Wechsler was born in a [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish]] family in [[Lespezi]], [[Romania]], and emigrated with his parents to the [[United States]] as a child. He studied at the [[City College of New York]] and [[Columbia University]], where he earned his master's degree in 1917 and his Ph.D. in 1925 under the direction of [[Robert S. Woodworth]]. During [[World War I]], he worked with the [[United States Army]] to develop psychological tests to screen new draftees while studying under [[Charles Spearman]] and [[Karl Pearson]]. After short stints at various locations (including five years in private practice), Wechsler became chief [[psychologist]] at [[Bellevue Hospital Center|Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital]] in 1932, where he stayed until 1967. He died on May 2, 1981.{{cite news |author=[[Wolfgang Saxon]] |coauthors= |title=Dr. David Wechsler, 85, Author Of Intelligence Tests |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/obituaries/dr-david-wechsler-85-author-of-intelligence-tests.html |quote=Dr. David Wechsler, a psychologist who was the author of widely used intelligence tests, died yesterday at his home on Manhattan's East Side. He was 85 years old. |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 3, 1981 |accessdate=2014-08-18 }} ==Intelligence scales== Wechsler is best known for his intelligence tests. He was one of the most influential advocates of the role of nonintellective factors in testing. He emphasized that factors other than intellectual ability are involved in intelligent behavior.Kaplan, R. M. & Saccuzzo, O. P. (2009). Psychological testing: Principles, applications, and issues (7 ed.), (pp. 250). Belmont, CA: Wadsworth. Wechsler objected to the single score offered by the 1937 Binet scale. Although his test did not directly measure nonintellective factors, it took these factors into careful account in its underlying theory.Kaplan, R. M. & Saccuzzo, O. P. (2009). Psychological testing: Principles, applications, and issues (7 ed., pp 250-251). Belmont, CA: Wadsworth. The [[Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale]] (WAIS) was developed first in 1939 and then called the Wechsler-Bellevue Intelligence Test. From these he derived the [[Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children]] (WISC) in 1949 and the [[Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence]] (WPPSI) in 1967. Wechsler originally created these tests to find out more about his patients at the Bellevue clinic and he found the then-current [[Stanford-Binet IQ test|Binet IQ test]] unsatisfactory. The tests are still based on his philosophy that intelligence is "the global capacity to act purposefully, to think rationally, and to deal effectively with [one's] environment" (cited in Kaplan & Saccuzzo, p. 256). The Wechsler scales introduced many novel concepts and breakthroughs to the intelligence testing movement. First, he did away with the quotient scores of older intelligence tests (the Q in "[[Intelligence quotient|I.Q.]]"). Instead, he assigned an arbitrary value of 100 to the mean intelligence and added or subtracted another 15 points for each [[standard deviation]] above or below the mean the subject was. While not rejecting the concept of [[g factor (psychometrics)|general intelligence]] (as conceptualized by his teacher [[Charles Spearman]]), he divided the concept of [[intelligence (trait)|intelligence]] into two main areas: verbal and performance (non-verbal) scales, each evaluated with different subtests. == References == {{reflist}} == Bibliography == * {{Cite book |title=The Wechsler Enterprise: An Assessment of the Development, Structure, and Use of the Wechsler Tests of Intelligence |last=Frank |first=George |year=1983 |publisher=Pergamon |location=Oxford |isbn=0-08-027973-2 |ref=harv }} * {{Cite book |title=Psychological Testing: Principles, Applications, and Issues |last1=Kaplan |first1=Robert M. |last2=Saccuzzo |first2=Dennis P. |year=2009 |edition=Seventh |publisher=Wadsworth |location=Belmont (CA) |isbn=978-0-495-09555-2}} * {{Cite book |title=Intelligent Testing with the WISC-V |last=Kaufman |first=Alan S. |authorlink=Alan S. Kaufman |series=Wiley |year=2016 |publisher=Wiley |location=New York (NY) |isbn=978-1118589236 |ref=harv }} * {{Cite book |title=IQ Testing 101 |last=Kaufman |first=Alan S. |authorlink=Alan S. Kaufman |year=2009 |publisher=Springer Publishing |location=New York |isbn=978-0-8261-0629-2}} * {{Cite book |title=Assessing Adolescent and Adult Intelligence |last1=Kaufman |first1=Alan S. |last2=Lichtenberger |first2=Elizabeth |authorlink1=Alan S. Kaufman |edition=3rd |year=2006 |publisher=Wiley |location=Hoboken (NJ) |isbn=978-0-471-73553-3}} * {{Cite book |title=The Measurement of Adult Intelligence |last=Wechsler |first=David |authorlink=David Wechsler |year=1939 |publisher=Williams & Witkins |location=Baltimore (MD) |ref=harv }} * {{Cite book |title=The Measurement and Appraisal of Adult Intelligence |last=Wechsler |first=David |authorlink=David Wechsler |year=1958 |edition=fourth |publisher=Williams & Witkins |location=Baltimore (MD) |ref=harv }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wechsler, David}} [[Category:1896 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:American people of Romanian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:City College of New York alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Educational psychologists]] [[Category:Intelligence researchers]] [[Category:Jewish American social scientists]] [[Category:Romanian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Romanian Jews]]

page.title: Faculty of Political Science and International Relations, Matej Bel University

revision.text:
{{Coord|48.7327|N|19.1452|E|display=title}} {{Infobox college | name = Faculty of Political Science and International Relations | parent = [[Matej Bel University]] | image = [[File:Logo of the Matej Bel School of Political Sciences and International Realations.png|200px|MBPSIR Logo]] | motto = ''Veritate et Legibus'' | motto_lang = la | established = 1995 | type = [[Public university|Public]] | dean = Branislav Kováčik | faculty = 51 | students = 783 | location = [[Banská Bystrica]], [[Slovakia]] | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | website = [http://www.fpvmv.umb.sk/ fpvmv.umb.sk] }} '''The Faculty of Political Science and International Relations''' at [[Matej Bel University]] ('''FPVaMV-UMB'''), ([[Slovak language|Slovakian]]: Fakulta politických vied a medzinárodných vzťahov Univerzity Mateja Bela v Banskej Bystrici) is a [[public policy]] and [[international relations]] teaching and research institution. It offers bachelor's degrees in political science and international relations, master's degrees in European studies, international relations and political science and also grants several doctoral degrees and conducts research in subjects relating to [[politics]], [[government]] and [[international relations|international affairs]].
Along with its Slovak taught programs the faculty also offers French [[dual degree]] programs in co-operation with the [[Versailles Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines University]], and English taught Master's and PhD. programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iufs.sk/menu/doubles-diplomes |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120905042725/http://www.iufs.sk/menu/doubles-diplomes |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-05 |title=IUFS |publisher=Iufs.sk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-04 }}</ref>
The faculty is widely recognized as one of the leading international relations institutes. The Academic Ranking and Rating Agency ranked the faculty's [[international relations|international affairs]] and [[diplomacy]] program first in nation, and among top in [[Central Europe]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvnoviny.sk/sekcia/spravy/domace/prinasame-rebricky-fakult-vysokych-skol.html |title=Prinášame rebríčky fakúlt vysokých škôl |publisher=tvnoviny.sk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120714060831/http://tvnoviny.sk/sekcia/spravy/domace/prinasame-rebricky-fakult-vysokych-skol.html |archivedate=2012-07-14 |df= }}</ref>
Since 2009 the faculty headquarters the National Center of Excellence for International Security Studies<ref name="projekty1">{{cite web |url=http://www.projekty.umb.sk/OPVaV/2.1/26220120010/umbbd.nsf |title=Centrum Excelentnosti Úvod |language=sk |publisher=Projekty.umb.sk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111013190757/http://www.projekty.umb.sk/OPVaV/2.1/26220120010/umbbd.nsf |archivedate=2011-10-13 |df= }}</ref> funded through the RD Program of the [[European Union|EU]].
==Campus== [[File:Courtyard of FPVMV.jpg|thumb|right|Courtyard of The Faculty of Political Science and International Relations, UMB]] The faculty campus is located in the historical city downtown of [[Banská Bystrica]], bordering the branch office of the [[National Bank of Slovakia]] and the Matej Bel University Rector´s department. The campus consists of two buildings, which are set in a 4-acre urban park overlooking the river [[Hron]]. The main building is an early 17th-century [[chateau]], which was completely reconstructed in 1995 and 2010. The second building is an early 17th-century servant's house, which served for many years as a headquarters for the faculty's various student organizations. Partially reconstructed by the Euro-Atlantic Center, it had been the headquarters for the Slovak Atlantic Commission and the Centre of Nations, until 2011 when the newly established Slovak-French university institute moved into this object.
==Academics== The faculty has had a distinctive international reputation since it was founded in 1995. The faculty's graduates have, on average, one of the largest salaries in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vs.iedu.sk/sk/profil/-/-/fakulta=f714060000 |title=Informácie o vysokých školách - Profil |publisher=Vs.iedu.sk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-04}}</ref>
===Admission=== The Faculty of Political Science and International Relations maintains a highly selective admission standard for its undergraduate programs. Applicants must have a completed secondary school education, reached the age of 17 or more and possess excellent knowledge in History, Geography, Economics, Current Global Issues and two foreign languages.
Applications for undergraduate programs must be sent before the end of February of the year the applicant would like to enroll. The application has to include a PVSS form, CV, and a certificated Report card from grade 9-12. In order to qualify for the applicant status, the school requires to pass the [[Maturita]] which is held nationwide in May. After the Maturita, students have to take an admission test at the faculty. The questions are postulated in Slovak, English and a second foreign language (German, Spanish, French, Russian.
The content of the questions for programs offered by the department of "International Relations" is from the areas of: Politics, World and Slovak History, [[International Relations]] and Diplomacy, Geography, Culture, Economic theory and current Slovak and World News. The content of the questions for programs offered by the department of "Political Science" is from the areas : Politics, World and Slovak History, Sociology, Culture, Economic theory, Slovak and International Law and current Slovak and World News.
The main factor for admission is the average percentage from the admission test, assistant factors are not including.<ref>{{sk icon}} http://www.umb.sk/umb/umbbb.nsf/DD247A50D6D8D111C1257A00002AF0AE/$File/VS_o_cinnosti_UMB_za_rok_2011_tabulkova_cast.pdf</ref>
The school's undergraduate admission rate in 2011 was 34,9%
===Academic departments===
The faculty consists of the following departments:
* '''Department of International Relations and Diplomacy'''
The Department of International Relations and Diplomacy deals with teaching activities related to the following subjects: Diplomacy, Diplomatic and Consular Law, European Studies, Geopolitics of the Slovak Republic, Humanitarian Law, Integration Processes and Basic Principles of European Law, Canadian Studies, etc. The department also offers a [[doctoral degree]] program in [[international relations]] and [[diplomacy]].
[[File:Conference at FPVMV.jpg|thumb|Conference with HE Jean-Marie BRUNO - ambassador of France to Slovakia and HE Axel Hartmann - ambassador of Germany to Slovakia]]
* '''Department of Politics'''
The Department of Politics provides full-time bachelor's and master’s programs in "International Relations" and "Political Science" as well as a full-time doctoral program in "Theory of politics".
* '''Department of Security Studies'''
The Department of Security Studies focuses on applied political issues for example, [[globalization]] and regional problems, socioeconomic geography of regions in the world, geography of the Slovak republic and [[political geography]].
* '''Department of Foreign Languages and International Communication'''
===Center of excellence=== The Faculty of Political Science and International Relations headquarters the National Center of Excellence for International Security Studies.<ref name="projekty1"/> The Center is funded by the Operational Program for Science and Research of the [[European Regional Development Fund]]. Its main goals are to * Produce cutting-edge academic research by encouraging integrated, multidisciplinary approaches to traditional and emerging challenges to security * Develop the next generation of academics and practitioners by providing high quality postgraduate education in international security * Broaden and deepen public understanding of the nexus between interstate conflict, transnational forces and human insecurity * Produces original and impartial research of (key) modern security issues, and makes this analysis available to policymakers, scholars, journalists, and the public.<ref>{{cite web|author=UMB BB |url=http://www.umb.sk/umb/umbbb.nsf/page/Projekty_strukturalnych_fondov_EU?OpenDocument&TableRow=2.1.1 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130418130432/http://www.umb.sk/umb/umbbb.nsf/page/Projekty_strukturalnych_fondov_EU?OpenDocument&TableRow=2.1.1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-04-18 |title=Univerzita Mateja Bela - Projekty štrukturálnych fondov EÚ |language=sk |publisher=Umb.sk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-04 }}</ref>
===Academic Publishing=== The faculty publishes the ''Politické vedy'' journal which was run from 1998-2000 in cooperation with the Institute of Political Sciences at the [[Slovak Academy of Sciences]], but since 2000 it has been exclusively administrated by the Faculty of Political Science and International Relations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upv.sav.sk/index.php?ID=118 |title=Politické vedy - 1998 - 2000 |publisher=Upv.sav.sk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-04}}</ref>
===Partnerships=== As a part of its internationally focused education, it encourages students to add an international component to their studies by living in a foreign country. The school believes that the experience is a key part of an education in international affairs because it increases understanding of the world by providing students with a variety of new and unexpected perspectives. The program functions as bilateral partnerships with a number of schools.
Some of these include [[The London School of Economics]] in UK, [[Indiana University]] in US, [[University of Bologna]] in Italy, [[University of Cologne]] in Germany, [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] in Belgium, [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Serbia)]] - Diplomatic Academy, [[Complutense University of Madrid]] in Spain etc. The faculty constantly looks for new partners and schools are added on a yearly basis.
In 2011, the faculty established the [https://web.archive.org/web/20120518200110/http://www.iufs.sk/lang/fr Slovak-French University Institute], in partnership with the [[French Embassy]] in Slovakia and two French Universities. The institute is headquartered on the school's campus and its main goal is to support [[scientific]] [[cooperation]] and [[academic mobility]] between French and Slovakian universities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esn.sk/article/international-day-matej-bel-university?page=1 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120804013731/http://www.esn.sk/article/international-day-matej-bel-university?page=1 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-08-04 |title=International Day at Matej Bel University | ESN Slovakia |publisher=Esn.sk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-04 }}</ref>
==Student life==
===Student body=== [[File:Debating club MB school of political sciences and international relations.jpg|thumb|Debating club - Video conference with Ioannis Vrailas, deputy head of the European Union Delegation to the United Nations]] There are about 600 full-time students and 100 part-time students at the faculty.
Student organizations at FPVaMV-UMB provide students with opportunities to get involved in a wide variety of interest areas including academic, social, religious, artistic, service-based, diversity and many more.
===Greek life=== The Faculty of Political Science and International Relations of Matej Bel University is home to the Sigma Phi Kappa<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/pages/SIGMA-PHI-KAPPA/322043315439 |title=Sigma Phi Kappa |publisher=Facebook |date=2012-06-16 |accessdate=2012-07-04}}</ref> fraternity. However, there is no "Greek row" on campus, nor is the fraternity formally acknowledged by the faculty. Activities of SPK are wide-ranging and include the organization of sporting events, organizing student parties, participating in fund raising events and more. The Sigma Phi Kappa also publishes a newsletter called PARTA HREJ.
SPK's symbol is a [[platypus]], representative colors are yellow and light blue.
==Administration== The school is administrated by the Dean's department. The school's scientific and research tasks are however determined by the Scientific Board. The main governing body of the school is the Academic Senate.
The faculty's current dean is Associate Professor Branislav Kováčik. The first dean of the faculty was Peter Kulašik, formerly a senior scientist at the Political Science Institute of the Slovak Academy of Sciences.
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.fpvmv.umb.sk/ }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120518200110/http://www.iufs.sk/lang/fr Slovak-French university Institute homepage]

revision.comment: Additional information about financial literacy month in Canada.
revision.text:
{{Globalize |date=September 2013 |discuss=Talk:Financial Literacy Month#Globalize }} '''National Financial Literacy Month''' is recognized in the United States in April in an effort to highlight the importance of [[financial literacy]] and teach Americans how to establish and maintain healthy financial habits.<ref>Senate Resolution 316; sponsored by Sen. Daniel Akaka D-HI</ref>
In 2000, The National Endowment for Financial Education introduced Youth Financial Literacy Day and turned it over to the Jump$tart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy so that the event would not promote any one organization and instead focus on financial literacy as a whole. The Jump$tart Coalition and its approximately 150 partners expanded the event to a month.
In 2003, the [[United States Senate]] designated April as ''Financial Literacy for Youth Month''. In March 2004 the Senate passed Resolution 316 that officially recognized April as ''National Financial Literacy Month''.
Many{{Weasel-inline|date=May 2010}} of the country’s [[financial institutions]] and [[nonprofit]] financial educational organizations promote the month{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} by holding promotional events and creating educational materials that center around effectively handling money and dealing with debt.
==Educational initiatives== {{see also|Financial Literacy Curriculum}} [[Money Management International]], a nonprofit credit and debt counseling firm, created a [[microsite]] to support the mission of National Financial Literacy Month, with a step by step process for improving financial wellness.
==Government support== In 2003 the [[United States Congress]] showed its support for the idea of a financial literacy month. Senate Resolution 48 and House Resolution 127 asked President [[George W. Bush]] to declare April Financial Literacy for Youth Month. At that time, governors of eight states had already named the month of April as such.<ref>http://www.jumpstartcoalition.org/fileuptemp/AprilFinancialLiteracyMonth.doc</ref> April was named National Financial Literacy Month by the passing of Senate Resolution 316 with [[unanimous consent]].<ref>http://www.jumpstartcoalition.org/fileuptemp/AprilFinancialLiteracyMonth.doc and http://www.jumpstartcoalition.org/fileuptemp/FINAL%20PR%202004%20Legislator%20Award.pdf</ref>
In April 2005, the [[United States House of Representatives]] passed a bill supporting the goals and ideals of Financial Literacy Month.<ref name=2005house>http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:HE00148:@@@L&summ2=m&</ref> This bill, and the resolution passed by the Senate, called on President Bush to issue a proclamation calling on Federal Government, States, localities, schools, nonprofit organizations business and the people of the United States to observe the month with appropriate programs and activities.<ref name=2005house/> During his term in office, President Bush did not issue a proclamation.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}}
During Financial Literacy Month in 2006, The [[Financial Literacy and Education Commission]] unveiled a new national strategy in their report "Taking Ownership of the Future: The National Strategy for Financial Literacy". The report outlined a series of outreach and education goals for the public and private sectors aimed to help Americans improve their understanding of financial issues such as credit management, savings, and homeownership.<ref>http://www.mymoney.gov/pdfs/ownership.pdf</ref>
Throughout the years, multiple states have also proclaimed April as Financial Literacy Month including [http://www.cscuf.coop/repository/arkansas+proclamation.pdf Arkansas], [http://www.cscuf.coop/repository/Oklahoma+April+Proclamation+optimized.pdf Oklahoma], [http://www.legis.state.pa.us/cfdocs/billInfo/billInfo.cfm?sYear=2017&sInd=0&body=H&type=R&bn=0777 Pennsylvania], and [http://www.cscuf.coop/repository/Texas+April+Proclamation.pdf Texas].
==Financial Literacy Month in Canada== Differing from the US, November is Canada’s Financial Literacy Month. The month is organized by the Financial Literacy Action Group (FLAG), a coalition of 7 non-profit organizations who work with the federal government body [[Financial Consumer Agency of Canada]] (FCAC).
Throughout November FLAG organizes events across Canada to educate and engage with the public regarding the need for financial literacy and promote services available to the public: “[FLAG] raises awareness of the need for financial literacy and highlights the programs, services and tools available to help Canadians improve their financial knowledge, skills and confidence.<ref>http://www.financialliteracymonth.ca/en/about-flm</ref>”
The purpose of this month is to educate the public so Canadians are equipped to:
- Provide for themselves and their family
- Invest in their future and the future of their children
- Understand their financial rights and obligations
- Contribute to the community as a good citizen
Similar to the United States, many of the country’s [[financial institutions]] (such as Planswell, Wealthsimple, RBC) and [[nonprofit]] financial educational organizations promote the month by creating educational material and hosting promotional events that center around topics of personal finances.
==References== <references />
==External links==
* [http://www.nefe.org The National Endowment for Financial Education (NEFE)] * [http://www.jumpstart.org Jump$tart Coalition for Personal Financial Literacy] * [http://www.nfcc.org National Foundation for Credit Counseling (NFCC)] * [http://www.financialliteracymonth.com FinancialLiteracyMonth.com] * [http://www.usmint.gov/kids/campCoin/financialLiteracy.cfm The United States Mint] * [http://www.mymoney.gov Financial Literacy and Education Commission (US)]
[[Category:Personal finance education]] [[Category:2004 in the United States]] [[Category:2004 in American politics]] [[Category:April observances]]

revision.comment: -[[Category:Charities based in Germany]]; + 2 categories; ±[[Category:Development charities]]→[[Category:Development charities based in Germany]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{third-party|date=August 2014}} '''The Friends of Waldorf Education''' (''Freunde der Erziehungskunst Rudolf Steiners e. V.''), referred to as the “Friends” below, is a [[Charitable organization|charity]] association founded in 1971 registered in [[Stuttgart]], Germany. The association fosters initiatives all over the world for a free education and organisations that work on the basis of [[Waldorf education]].
As umbrella organisation for the German government-sponsored Voluntary Services, the association places approximately 1000 volunteers per year both inside Germany and internationally.
The branch “Crisis or Emergency Education” of the Friends of Waldorf Education carries out international War and Catastrophe assistance for traumatised children and young people since 2006.
==History== in 1969, Waldorf education celebrated the 50th anniversary of its establishment and was expanding increasingly throughout the world. In order to bring together a group of people who would support the growing school movement both ideally and financially, [[Ernst Weissert]] founded the Friends of Waldorf Education on 10 October 1971.
Ernst Weissert himself did not stand for membership of the Executive, leaving this task to his closest assistant and second member, Dr. Manfred Leist. Other members of the Executive were Günter Ziegenbein (member of the Board of the Waldorf school in the Kräherwald, Stuttgart), and Armin Scholter, the administrator of the same school. This guaranteed a secure existence for the association. Many former students of the Waldorf school, Uhlandshöhe became members and have, to a great extent, remained so until today. Both Ernst Weissert and Manfred Leist had, however, other pressing tasks in building up the German school’s movement and within the leadership of the [[:de:Bund der Freien Waldorfschulen|Bund der Freien Waldorfschulen]], so that there was little time left over for this association.
In 1976, certain former Waldorf students had the idea of founding a Worldwide School’s association. Ernst Weissert took up this intention and offered them the Association Friends of Waldorf Education as a legal entity. Andreas Büttner, Nana Göbel and Justus Wittich were elected onto the executive in November 1978, Günther Ziegenbein and Armin Scholter withdrew. The association was renamed “Freunde der Erziehungskunst Rudolf Steiners” (Friends of the Art of Education of Rudolf Steiner). Under the guidance of the new executive, the international support and networking activity was built up, amongst others with the newly founded International Aid Fund.
In 1994 the Friends were invited by [[UNESCO]] to attend the International Education Conference in Geneva in order to present Waldorf Education before an international public. This co-work with UNESCO continued and in May 2001 the Friends of Waldorf Education established official relations with UNESCO.<ref>Freunde der Erziehungskunst Rudolf Steiners (Hrsg.): ''Waldorfpädagogik weltweit.'' Berlin, 2001, S. 12–17.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://ngo-db.unesco.org/r/or/en/1100053723|title= Friends of Waldorf Education|work=ngo-db.unesco.org|date= |accessdate=2014-08-15}}</ref>
Today the association employs about 90 co-workers and has two branches, one in [[Berlin]] and another in [[Karlsruhe]]
In the executive of the association are Nana Göbel, Bernd Ruf, [[Henning Kullak-Ublick]] and Andreas Schubert.
==Areas of work== The work of the Friends consists of different areas of activity, all of which stand in relation to and serve Waldorf education.
=== Project support/International Aid Fund === The Friends support Waldorf schools, Waldorf kindergartens, and anthroposophical [[Special education]] organisations throughout the world through donations but also through counselling, networking, mentoring etc. The association has no capital of its own, is thus not a foundation, but receives donations and legacies from many different individual donors, from Waldorf schools and other institutions and from foundations connected with it. These it uses in accordance with the wishes of the donors, for is important for the Friends that the donors themselves decide who or what they wish to support.
95% of all donations received by the Friends are for a specific pre-defined purpose. The donors support institutions to which they themselves have a relationship, because of a report they have read or some other personal reason.
In order to support essential larger investments, the Friends work together with foundations and other aid funds, as well as with the [[Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development|BMZ]] (Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development).
===Voluntary services=== Since 1993 the Friends have promoted and organised international voluntary services.
Volunteers work in Waldorf educational or anthroposophicallly oriented institutions, communities (of persons with and without disability), schools, nursery schools and social projects.
A year of social service abroad can be arranged with the Friends through the following (German) state funded programmes: * [http://www.internationaler-jugend-freiwilligendienst.de/ Internationaler Jugendfreiwilligendienst ](IJFD) * Entwicklungspolitischer Freiwilligendienst * [[:de:Anderer Dienst im Ausland|Anderer Dienst im Ausland]] (ADiA)
The Friends are certified for this international social service work with the Quifd Quality Seal Quifd-Gütesiegel (Qualität im Freiwilligendienst).
From 2011, the association offers voluntary services within Germany itself. * [[:de:Bundesfreiwilligendienst|Bundesfreiwilligendienst]] (BFD) * [[:de:Freiwilliges Soziales Jahr|Freiwilliges Soziales Jahr]] (FSJ)
In 2006 the Friends were authorised to offer a year of social service to international volunteers in Germany. This “incoming” programme has been incorporated into the State Voluntary Services since 2011.
===Educational Godparenting=== At the end of the 1990s the organisation of educational godparents was taken up as a new area of engagement in order to enable individual children in countries where Waldorf schools receive no state funding, having therefore to rely entirely on fee income, to nevertheless attend a Waldorf school.
Godparents constitute a quite individual form of assistance. Waldorf schools have from the beginning been dedicated and open to all human beings and classes of society. It should not depend on the economic situation of the parents whether a child is able to attend a Waldorf school or not. In this manner the godparents support the individual child and also the whole school community.
Thus far the association has organised around 700 godparents.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.freunde-waldorf.de/fileadmin/user_upload/documents/Die_Freunde/Publikationen/Rundbrief/RB_2013_H.pdf|title= Bildungspatenschaften – Rundbrief der Freunde der Erziehungskunst – Herbst 2013|publisher=Friends of Waldorf Education|date= |accessdate=2014-08-15}}</ref> These support the equivalent number of children at over 50 schools with amounts ranging between 25 and 200 Euros per month.
===WOW-Day=== From 1994 on, students have engaged themselves on one day of the year for Waldorf initiatives the world over. By means of artistic endeavours or day jobs they collect money for Waldorf institutions and projects that are in need of financial assistance.
With the help of the Friends and their partner organisations, the Bund der Freien Waldorfschulen and the European Council for Steiner Waldorf Education, the student campaign has grown from year to year. Students learn to become engaged on behalf of others and to take an interest in other cultural environments as well as experiencing how to organise community events and transform their ideas into reality.
Over 200 Waldorf schools participate each year in more than 30 countries on a commonly agreed day in Autumn.
Around 2.5 million Euros have been collected by students on the WOW-Days since 1994 (2013) and have supported over 100 organisations worldwide.
Collected donations are first paid into the account of the Friends of Waldorf Education, who undertake to transfer 100% of the amount on to the projects.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.freunde-waldorf.de/fileadmin/user_upload/documents/Die_Freunde/Publikationen/Rundbrief/RB_2013_H.pdf|title= WOW-Day – Rundbrief der Freunde der Erziehungskunst Rudolf Steiners, Herbst 2013|publisher=Friends of Waldorf Education|date=|accessdate=2014-08-15}}</ref>
===Crisis or emergency education=== Emergency or crisis education concerns itself with the psychological stabilising of children and young people in warfare and the aftermaths of natural catastrophes. To date over 25 engagements have taken place in nine different countries.
Curative teacher Bernd Ruf developed a comprehensive concept based on the insights of Waldorf education for this Emergency education after he had experienced the results of trauma on children in a refugee camp in Beirut during the war in Lebanon in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treuhandstelle-hh.de/files/Hinweis_2012_11.pdf|title=hinweis – November 2012|work=treuhandstelle-hh.de|date=|accessdate=2014-08-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203210003/http://www.treuhandstelle-hh.de/files/Hinweis_2012_11.pdf|archivedate=2014-02-03|df=}}</ref> Following on armed conflicts and natural catastrophes the Friends have thus far worked in Lebanon (2006, 2013), China (2008, 2013), Gaza (2009 – 2013), Indonesia (2009), Haiti (2010), Kirgistan (2010), Japan (2011), and Kenya (2012, 2013). They are members of the aid organisation Aktion Deutschland Hilft (ADH) and work in cooperation with partners such as the organisation [[Habitat for Humanity]] in Chile.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aktion-deutschland-hilft.de/de/fachthemen/katastrophenvorsorge/informationsaustausch/|title= Katastrophenvorsorge - Informationsaustausch zweier Mitgliedsorganisationen von Aktion Deutschland Hilft|publisher=Aktion Deutschland Hilft|date= |accessdate=2014-08-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.aktion-deutschland-hilft.de/en/member-organisations/friends-of-waldorf-education/|title= Friends of Waldorf Education Emergency Pedagogy Division|publisher= Aktion Deutschland Hilft|date=|accessdate=2014-08-15}}</ref>
==Literature== * Bernd Ruf: ''Trümmer und Traumata: Anthroposophische Grundlagen notfallpädagogischer Einsätze'' Ita-Wegmann-Institut, 2012, {{ISBN|3905919397}}, 9783905919394.
==External links== * [http://www.freunde-waldorf.de/en// Website of the Freunde der Erziehungskunst Rudolf Steiners e. V.]
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Infobox University | name = Ghana Baptist University College | native_name = | image_name = Ghana Baptist University College (GBUC) crest.jpg | image_size = frameless | caption = [[Coat of Arms|Arms]] of the Ghana Baptist University College | motto = Excellence in Leadership and Stewardship
Discover Yourself From Here | tagline = | established = November 2006 | type = [[Private university|Private]] | endowment = | staff = | faculty = | president = Dr Kojo Osei-Wusuh | provost = | principal = G.S. Mallet | chairman = | rector = | chancellor = | vice_chancellor = | dean = Dr Opoku | students = about 1900 | city = Kumasi, Amakom | state = | country = Ghana | campus = [[Urban area]]
Amakom, Kumasi
Abuakwa, [[Kumasi]] | colours = [[Azure (color)|Azure]], [[White]], [[Sky blue]] and [[Maize (color)|Maize]]
{{color box|#007FFF}} {{color box|#FFFFFF}} {{color box|#87CEEB}} {{color box|#FBEC5D}} | website = {{URL|www.gbuc.edu.gh}} | address = Ghana Baptist University College
Ghana Baptist Theological Seminary
P. O. Box 1
Abuakwa-Kumasi | logo = [[File:Ghana Baptist University College (GBUC) logo.jpg|235px]] }} The '''Ghana Baptist University College''' is a [[university college]] located at [[Kumasi]] in [[Ghana]]. Its establishment in November 2006 was announced by the Ghana Baptist Convention.{{cite web|url=http://www.bwanet.org/default.aspx?pid=301 |title=Ghana Baptists launch new university |accessdate=2007-03-22 |work=Newsletter |date=September 2006 |publisher=Baptist World Alliance |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928103313/http://www.bwanet.org/default.aspx?pid=301 |archivedate=September 28, 2007 }} The university has been granted accreditation by the [[National Accreditation Board (Ghana)|National Accreditation Board]]. The school is one of the leading names in terms of private universities in the nation.{{cite web |url=http://www.nab.gov.gh/nabsite/pages/accredited_institute3.php?skey=unicol&Search=Search |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019045941/http://www.nab.gov.gh/nabsite/pages/accredited_institute3.php?skey=unicol&Search=Search |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-10-19 |title=Accredited Institutions - University Colleges |accessdate=2007-03-22 |work=Official Website |publisher=National Accreditation Board }} ==History== The Ghana Baptist University has been formed partly from the Ghana Baptist Seminary. The Ghana Baptist University institution is affiliated to the University of Cape Coast through its Department for the Study of Religions.{{cite web|url=http://www.ug.edu.gh/facarts.php |title=Faculties and Departments - Faculty of Arts |accessdate=2007-03-22 |work=Official Website |publisher=University of Ghana}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==Campus== The university has two campuses. They are: *City Campus - Amakom *Abuakwa campus - Abuakwa *The Ghana Baptist Seminary at Abuakwa is part of the new university. ==Programmes== The university college has four programmes. * Bachelor of Theology * B.Sc Business Administration with options in Banking & Finance, Human Resource Management, Accounting, Marketing and Entrepreneurship * Diploma in Church Music * Diploma in Theology Others include:{{cite web |url=http://www.coursesghana.com/universities/761-ghana-baptist-university-college.aspx|title=Ghana Baptist University College Details |accessdate=2014-03-29 |publisher=CoursesGhana.com}} * Master of Arts in Ministry * Master of Theology * Bachelor of Nursing ==Affiliations== Ghana Baptist University College is affiliated to three institutions namely: * [[University of Cape Coast]]{{cite web|publisher=National Accreditation Board|url=http://www.nab.gov.gh/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=186:ghana-baptist-university-college&catid=60:private-tertiary-institutions-offering-degree-prog&Itemid=185|title=Private Tertiary Institutions Offering Degree Programmes|accessdate=2014-03-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130821114236/http://nab.gov.gh/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=186%3Aghana-baptist-university-college&catid=60%3Aprivate-tertiary-institutions-offering-degree-prog&Itemid=185|archivedate=2013-08-21|df=}} * Ghana Baptist Convention * Association of Ghana Private Universities ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100418160814/http://www.nab.gov.gh/nabsite/index.php universities}}{{-}} {{coord|6|41|29|N|1|36|27|W|region:GH-AH_type:edu_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}} [[Category:Education in Ghana]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Ghana]]
